children.subject: From what I know, this is the first time since being hired Professor Abebe is teaching an undergrad course, so there's no way to really know how she will run this class (she did teach a grad class last semester, so if you know any grad students who took it they could probably tell you what her teaching style is like). In terms of what this class is like, it's currently being taught by Professor Borgs, so maybe someone taking the class right now can speak on that :)

history.content:
<md>I am in CS194-198 right now, as it is being taught by Prof. Borgs currently. The course is probably most similar to other theoretical CS courses like 174/270 except that it has a heavy emphasis on Networks and Graphs.

The course does a lightning review of probability which leads into a unit on network structure. This mainly focused on some phase transitions that happen that cause certain structures to appear, like edges, triangles, connected components, etc. We then looked at different kinds of networks from random graphs to preferential attachment. Then we studied different processes on Networks like epidemics, random walks and page rank. It is here that Markov Chains become very important. After this, we are now looking at algorithms on graphs such as min-cut or detecting communities in networks from spectral clustering. 

The course lectures are very mathematical and proofs based. The homework is released every 2 weeks, and it is pretty mathematical stuff, focusing on analysis and proofs. The first 2 homeworks were pretty difficult, but the prof toned them down as the semester went on. This is the first year that Borgs has taught the class and he is basically experimenting with the class with the goal of making it a permanent part of the CS curriculum, so this year was pretty lenient on the grading, not sure how that will change. No midterms or projects, only 1 final. The prof posts handwritten lecture notes online and is pretty good at responding to questions. 

Overall, the class is pretty difficult conceptually, and some of the mathematics used is beyond what the average undergraduate in CS will see in an undergraduate course. If you find networks really interesting or if you have a strong math background, then the course shouldn't be a problem.  The prof. does make time to teach any advanced mathematical techniques to the class before he uses them, but you need a pretty mature mathematical foundation to get the most out of the class. I personally enjoyed this course more than CS161, but that is mainly due to my own theoretical interests. CS 161 is probably more useful in industry and easier conceptually, tho the workload of 161 is probably higher. </md>

I'm a rising senior interested to take either CS161 or CS194-198 (Networks: Models, Processes & Algorithms) in Fall 22. There's not much information on CS194-198 by Professor Rediet Abebe as far as I can find.

I would love to know where I can find more information on CS194-198 (in terms of course structure, logistics, and workload) and to have input on how to choose between CS161 and CS194-198. Thank you! Personally, I've taken CS170, CS186, CS188, CS189, and a couple of data science classes.
history.subject: CS194-198 Course Information?
